item.title: Robert Denoon Cumming on Sartrean Dialectics
item.description: Robert Denoon Cumming’s article “This Place of Violence, Obscurity, and Witchcraft” (1979) is a hidden gem. Utterly bizarre in style, it presents Sartre’s understanding of dialectics really nicely, in almost point form. The first thing, noted by Sartre himself, is that dialectics is less a systematic philosophy or explanation of how things work, but a way (methodos) of making things intelligible. The question is how. Cumming starts on a point I find particularly seductive: the idea of dialectic as “a method of sustained definition.

item.title: About
item.description: I’m a PhD candidate in Political Science. I wrote my dissertation on the concept of “domestic colonialism” in the United States, asking whether it could (or should) be reconstructed as an element of anticolonial critical theory today. My research and reading interests are in: Empire, race, and colonialism in political theory Philosophy and history of social science Dialectical philosophy and its relation to philosophy of history Twentieth-century engagements with radicalism in political theory

item.title: Robert Jackson's Quasi-Colonial Apologetics
item.description: It really is curious just how little work there is directly bearing on the history and theory of decolonization in twentieth-century international relations theory. Because the histories and explanations of particular decolonizing situations – say, in Malaysia, or Ghana, or Algeria, etc. – are handed off to historians and students of comparative politics, all that’s left for IR theory is, typically, the question of how decolonization both expanded and transformed the international system.
